text: A good man sheweth favour, and lendeth: he will guide his affairs with discretion.
text_kjv: A good man sheweth favour, and lendeth: he will guide his affairs with discretion.
text_niv: Good will come to him who is generous and lends freely,who conducts his affairs with justice.
text_esv: It is well with the man who deals generously and lends; who conducts his affairs with justice.
text_nlt: Good comes to those who lend money generouslyand conduct their business fairly.
text_msg: The good person is generous and lends lavishly;
text_nasb: It is well with the man who is gracious and lends; He will maintain his cause in judgment.
context: In ancient Israel, lending and borrowing were deeply intertwined with the social fabric and religious law. Deuteronomy 15 emphasized lending to the poor within the community and forbade charging interest to fellow Israelites. This was to prevent the wealthy from exploiting the vulnerable and to promote economic equity. Lending was seen as an act of compassion and obedience to God's commands, rather than merely a financial transaction. The concept of 'favour' in this context would have encompassed not just lending money, but also extending grace, help, and support to those in need. 'Guiding affairs with discretion' involved careful planning and wise management of resources, not just in personal finances but also in business dealings and community leadership. It required a keen awareness of the needs of others and a commitment to justice and fairness. Failure to show favour or to manage affairs wisely could lead to social ostracization and divine judgment. The social structure relied heavily on mutual support and responsible stewardship, making these actions crucial indicators of righteousness. Lending was often the only safety net for families facing hardship due to crop failure, illness, or other misfortunes. Lending to those in dire need was not just good moral standing but rather a cornerstone of the mosaic Law.
meaning: Psalm 112:5 presents a picture of a righteous individual whose actions reflect God's character. 'A good man sheweth favour, and lendeth' speaks to the virtue of generosity and compassion. It's not merely about lending money, but about extending kindness, grace, and practical help to those in need. This echoes God's own gracious provision for humanity. The act of lending, especially to the vulnerable, demonstrates a heart that is sensitive to suffering and committed to alleviating it. 'He will guide his affairs with discretion' highlights the importance of wisdom and prudence in all aspects of life. It suggests a deliberate and thoughtful approach to managing resources, making decisions, and conducting business. This discretion is not just about personal gain, but about ensuring fairness, justice, and integrity in all dealings. It reflects a desire to honor God through responsible stewardship and ethical conduct. The combination of generosity and prudence paints a picture of a balanced and mature faith. The good man doesn't simply give impulsively, but thoughtfully considers the needs of others and manages resources wisely to maximize their impact. The Psalm emphasizes that true righteousness manifests not only in outward acts of kindness but also in inward character and wisdom. This blend of compassion and discernment reflects the very nature of God, who is both merciful and just. It demonstrates a holistic approach to living a life that is pleasing to God.
application: In today's world, Psalm 112:5 challenges us to examine our own attitudes and actions towards those in need and our approach to managing our resources. 'Shewing favour, and lending' can manifest in various ways. It might involve financial giving to charities that support the vulnerable, or offering practical help to neighbors struggling with illness or unemployment. It could mean volunteering time and skills to organizations that serve the community. The key is to be attentive to the needs around us and to respond with compassion and generosity. Lending doesn't always mean lending money. It can also involve offering our skills, time, or support to others. 'Guiding affairs with discretion' applies to our personal finances, our professional lives, and our community involvement. It means making wise and ethical decisions, being responsible with our resources, and acting with integrity in all our dealings. It requires us to be informed, thoughtful, and considerate of the consequences of our actions. Practicing discretion also means avoiding impulsive or wasteful spending, investing wisely, and being mindful of the needs of others when making financial decisions. It also means managing our time and energy effectively, prioritizing our commitments, and avoiding over-commitment. In the workplace, it means conducting ourselves with honesty, fairness, and respect for others. It means being a responsible employer or employee, adhering to ethical standards, and striving to create a positive and productive work environment. Ultimately, Psalm 112:5 calls us to integrate our faith with our daily lives, to be generous and compassionate, and to act with wisdom and integrity in all that we do. We can be more intentional with our resources and actions to make positive impacts on those around us.
prayer: Heavenly Father, thank you for your boundless generosity and your example of showing favor to us. Help me to cultivate a heart that is sensitive to the needs of others and eager to lend a helping hand. Grant me wisdom to manage my resources with discretion, that I may be a faithful steward of all that you have entrusted to me. Guide my decisions in all areas of my life, that they may be pleasing to you and beneficial to those around me. Forgive me for times when I have been selfish or careless with my resources, or when I have failed to show compassion to those in need. Fill me with your love and your grace, that I may be a true reflection of your character in all that I do. Help me to remember that everything I have is a gift from you, and that I am called to use it for your glory and the good of others. In Jesus’ name, Amen.

faqs.answer: No, while it can include financial lending, 'lending' in this context broadly signifies extending aid, support, and resources – including time, skills, and encouragement – to those in need. The emphasis is on generosity and practical assistance.
faqs.question: Q1: Does 'lending' in this verse only refer to financial lending?

faqs.answer: Discretion ensures that generosity is effective and sustainable. It encourages thoughtful giving based on discernment, avoiding impulsive acts that may not truly help or could enable harmful behavior. Wisdom guides our compassion.
faqs.question: Q2: How does 'discretion' relate to generosity? Shouldn't we just give freely?

faqs.answer: Absolutely. 'Lending' isn't solely about material wealth. You can lend your time, skills, encouragement, or a listening ear. The key is to use what you have, no matter how small, to help others in need.
faqs.question: Q3: What if I don't have much to lend? Does this verse still apply to me?

faqs.answer: In the workplace, discretion involves ethical decision-making, responsible use of company resources, fair treatment of colleagues, and maintaining professional boundaries. It’s about integrity in all your dealings.
faqs.question: Q4: How can I practically apply 'guiding my affairs with discretion' in my workplace?

faqs.answer: Modern examples include donating to reputable charities, volunteering time at a local shelter, mentoring a young person, offering a ride to someone in need, or simply offering a kind word or gesture of support.
